title: RS21282
content: The Military Personnel Records division of the National Personnel Records Center in St. Louis, Missouri, holds U.S. military personnel records from World War I to present. Records can be requested online, by mail, or fax. The NPRC does not intend to destroy physical records. Veterans and their next-of-kin (NOK) can request military personnel records from the National Personnel Records Center in St. Louis. The NOK is defined differently for each branch of the military. If an individual does not meet the NOK definition, they can request records via the Freedom of Information Act. A fire in 1973 destroyed millions of Army and Air Force files, but NPRC uses alternate sources to fulfill requests. The National Personnel Records Center in St. Louis uses alternate sources to respond to requests for military personnel files. More information can be found on their website or by contacting the center directly. Older military records are located at the National Archives in Washington, DC. For guidance on corrections and military review boards, refer to NARA's resources. For information on correcting military service records, refer to the Boards for Correction of Military Records (BCMR) site. Prior to submitting a request to a BCMR, utilize all administrative avenues, including NPRC and the military service department. NPRC also provides guidance on requesting military awards and decorations, replacing medals, and obtaining a Cold War Recognition Certificate. The National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 1998 (P.L. 105-85) requires the Secretary to provide military service records for servicemembers who separated before or during 1956. Records for those who separated after 1956 can be requested through FOIA. The general public can purchase a copy of a veteran's OMPF to determine awards and obtain medals from a commercial source. Requests for military service medals, decorations, and awards can be made online or via mail to the National Personnel Records Center or Coast Guard Personnel Service Center. The Cold War Recognition Certificate, established by the NDAA for Fiscal Year 1998, recognizes the service of qualifying members of the Armed Forces and civilian personnel from September 2, 1945, to December 26, 1991. The Modern Military Records office at NARA holds records for various conflicts, but some records, like those for Army units in the interwar periods, are incomplete. For more information, contact the Textual Records office at the National Archives and Records. To access military unit records, contact the Textual Records office at the National Archives and Records Administration in College Park. If records are not publicly available, submit a FOIA request to the agency holding the records. For special access records at the National Archives at College Park, contact the Archives FOIA office. Visit https://www.foia.gov/how-to.html for more information on submitting a FOIA request for various types of auxiliary and organizational records. The National Archives in St. Louis, Missouri maintains rolls, U.S. Army Surgeon General's office records, and Veterans Administration index cards. Veterans can access military unit records for disability claims by reviewing Army morning reports, unit rosters, pay cards, Navy muster rolls, Captain logs/Navy Deck logs, etc. More information on military exposures can be found on the VA's Military Exposure site. VA is studying the long-term health issues of deployed veterans and their exposure to burn pits. The VA is studying the long-term health issues of deployed veterans exposed to burn pits in Iraq and Afghanistan. There is currently no compensation available for this exposure. For more information, visit the VA's Public Health site on Burn Pits. The Purple Heart: Background and Issues for Congress, U.S. Periods of War and Dates of Recent Conflicts, American Battle Monuments Commission (ABMC) and Civil War Soldiers and Sailors System provide databases and information on veterans, military cemeteries, and historical records. Confederate States of America (CSA) Records at the Library of Congress contain records spanning the CSA history. The CSA records cover the years 1854-1889, with a focus on the Civil War period from 1861-1865. Links are provided to Official Records of the Union and Confederate Armies, Official Records of the Union and Confederate Navies, and War Department Collection of Confederate Records. The National Archives Library Information Center offers resources on veterans, military casualties, POW/MIAs, and medals & honors. Additionally, Philippine Army and Guerilla Records are available at the National Archives, including records of the Philippine Commonwealth Army and recognized Philippine Guerrilla forces. During World War II, the Veterans History Project (VHP) at the Library of Congress collects personal accounts of American veterans. The Veterans Affairs (VA) Nationwide Gravesite Locator database contains burial locations of veterans and their family members. Various resources are available for military history research, including guides to Confederate and Purple Heart recipients, as well as the Order of Battle of the United States Land Forces in the World War. The curr_chunk provides a list of military history resources including bibliographies, order of battle references, and guides for locating military personnel.
